propositions.text: This is a TXT novel titled "盗墓笔记之7：阴山古楼" by 南派三叔.
It is hosted on the website TXT小说天堂.
The website provides classic literature, martial arts, romance, and humanities/social science books for online reading and free mobile download.
TXT小说天堂 aims to provide classic and complete novels, not necessarily the most numerous.
The narrator is recovering from a traumatic experience in Gormo.
He has been having nightmares for three months.
He feels that revealing secrets comes with a burden of suffering.
He questions if he can truly escape his past.
He has written down all the events of the past year, starting from his grandfather's notes.
He worries about forgetting the past, comparing it to wearing a mask too long.

He still has many unanswered questions about the events, including the whereabouts of his uncle, the true identity of Mute Bottle, the fate of Wen Jin, the nature of the 'ultimate', the builders of the underground ruins, and the plans of Wen Jin's group.
Mute Bottle has been sent to Peking University First Hospital for a full examination.
His physical condition is fine, but his consciousness is not fully clear.
The narrator has been trying to gather information about Mute Bottle's background from people in Changsha, but without success.
Fatty claims to have a way to find information about Mute Bottle's past.
The narrator believes understanding Mute Bottle's past is more difficult than anticipated.
If Mute Bottle doesn't recover, they may have to care for him indefinitely.
The narrator fears Mute Bottle might remember things but not clearly.
Pan Zi miraculously survived and has recovered quickly.
The situation in Changsha is chaotic after the disappearance of Uncle.
Uncle's businesses have been significantly impacted by Chen Pi Si.
Pan Zi is considering retiring due to the instability.
The narrator advises Pan Zi to settle down and start a family.
Pan Zi remains unsettled due to Uncle's uncertain fate and may continue searching for him.
Fatty has returned to Beijing to resume his business.
Fatty's parting words, '青山不改绿水长流，后会有期' (May we meet again), carry a deeper meaning for those who have experienced life and death together.
Zaxi parted ways with them in Gormo after helping them escape the Taklamakan Desert.
Zaxi refused payment, considering the experience a personal karma.
The narrator gave Zaxi his watch as a memento.
Ah Ning is dead, and the narrator has lost contact with Jude Kaw's company.
He believes that after this failure, Jude Kaw should give up.
Life seems to be returning to normal for everyone.
The narrator has returned to his routine life in Hangzhou.
He feels a sense of time distortion when looking at his grandfather's notes.
He relates to the Zhuang Zhou's butterfly dream, feeling that the past year's events were dreamlike and fleeting.
He contemplates the possibility that his current peace might be a pre-death delusion.
He is prepared to accept either outcome.
He understands that the matter is far from over.
Two weeks later, Mute Bottle is discharged from the hospital.
The narrator meets with Fatty and Mute Bottle in Beijing to discuss future plans.
The narrator's most pressing issue is dealing with Uncle's abandoned affairs.
He needs to explain the recent significant events to his family without their knowledge of the drastic changes.
With Mute Bottle's consciousness returning, the narrator must re-establish their relationship.
Mute Bottle has no known family, no possessions, and no identification, making his situation precarious.
Fatty is doing well and has opened a new establishment in Liulichang.
Mute Bottle appears to have regained his former demeanor, though his gaze is distant, suggesting a detachment from the world.
Mute Bottle expresses a desire to travel and revisit places like Changsha and Shandong to try and regain his memories.
The narrator is concerned about Mute Bottle's memory recovery, fearing it will lead to further pain.
Fatty suggests a plan: Fatty will rent a place, the narrator will hire a caregiver, and they will support Mute Bottle nearby.
The narrator believes they should ask Mute Bottle his own wishes.
Mute Bottle wishes to travel and explore various locations to try and remember his past.
The narrator is reluctant to see Mute Bottle go back to his old ways.
Fatty reminds the narrator to let things happen naturally.
The narrator decides to accompany Mute Bottle and help him navigate his memory recovery.
The narrator asks Fatty about his previous claim of having a way to know Mute Bottle's background.
Fatty explains that he had planned to inquire with 'jia lamas' (middlemen) who might have information about Mute Bottle's connection to Uncle.
The 'jia lamas' refused to share any information.
The narrator realizes that the 'jia lamas' operate by their own rules and may be afraid of repercussions.
Fatty suggests that Mute Bottle should go on a guided tour and that they should prepare money for him.
The narrator has an idea about using someone who might be willing to talk.
He recalls 'Brother Chu' (Chu Guotou), who helped Uncle with 'jia lama' duties in Changbai Mountain.
Brother Chu is a boss of an underground money exchange who is currently imprisoned.
He might have information about Mute Bottle and Fatty, and being in prison, may have fewer concerns.
Fatty agrees that this is a good idea, but worries about Brother Chu reporting them.
The narrator believes that Brother Chu, being shrewd, might be willing to talk if approached correctly, especially given his current predicament.
The narrator plans to ask Pan Zi to discreetly inquire about Brother Chu's situation.
They decide to help Mute Bottle investigate his past, believing it's better than him wandering alone.
The narrator asks Fatty to accompany Mute Bottle.
Fatty agrees, emphasizing the importance of finding Mute Bottle's residence.
The narrator calls Pan Zi to explain the situation and ask for his help in contacting Brother Chu.
Pan Zi, known for his loyalty, agrees and is highly efficient.
Three days later, Pan Zi calls back with news.
Brother Chu knows the information they seek but has conditions.
He demands ten thousand yuan and requests a personal meeting with the narrator.
The narrator is surprised by the demand for a meeting, suspecting ulterior motives.
He fears Brother Chu might be trying to lure him out to gain favor or betray them.
Pan Zi also finds the request suspicious.
Brother Chu instructs Pan Zi to deliver a 'very old photograph' to the narrator, believing it will convince him to meet.
The narrator suspects this photograph might be related to the photo from before Uncle's trip to Xisha, which caused him to waste time.
He wonders if Brother Chu knows the hidden reasons behind that event.
Pan Zi describes the photograph as a very old, black-and-white photo from his youth.
Pan Zi cannot definitively say what is in the photo but feels it depicts a 'ghost'.
The photograph is emailed to the narrator.
It is a yellowed, faded black-and-white photo, likely taken in an old house.
The background is a screen, and a figure stands behind it, appearing unnaturally straight and with slumped shoulders.
The narrator initially feels uneasy and questions its relevance to his interest.
The photo shows a corridor behind the screen with multiple doors.
The scan of the back of the photo reveals Brother Chu's handwriting: '1984, Gormo PLA Sanatorium'.
The narrator realizes it's the abandoned sanatorium in Gormo, a former hiding place for Wen Jin and her group.
He speculates that Brother Chu might be involved or received something from Uncle.
He considers that the photo might have been taken due to a specific event that occurred there.
He believes the photograph was intended to capture the shadow behind the screen, possibly due to its eerie appearance.
He concludes that the sanatorium holds many secrets and that the photo is evidence of something significant that happened there.
He decides he must meet Brother Chu.
The narrator arranges to meet Brother Chu at Pingtang Prison.
Brother Chu appears thinner and older, his demeanor suggesting stress and fear.
Brother Chu asks about Uncle and expresses a belief that his current situation is a consequence of his profession.
He asks why the narrator is inquiring about 'Mute Zhang' (the nickname for Mute Bottle).
Pan Zi interjects, questioning Brother Chu's interrogation.
Brother Chu, despite his dire circumstances, remains defiant.
The narrator tries to de-escalate the situation.
Brother Chu acknowledges the narrator's connection to Uncle.
Brother Chu confirms that Pan Zi has paid his father the ten thousand yuan.
Brother Chu asks Pan Zi to leave, stating that the conversation is between him and the narrator.
After Pan Zi leaves, Brother Chu's demeanor changes, and he warns the narrator to stop investigating.
He cites the dire fates of himself, Uncle, and Mute Bottle as a warning.
He describes the subsequent events as too astonishing for ordinary people to handle.
The narrator presses him for details, referencing the photograph.
Brother Chu reveals he knows a great deal because he used to implement many of Uncle's plans, including investigating Chen Wen Jin.
He states that he is telling the narrator because he is not part of the underground world and that Uncle often mentioned him.
He explains that Uncle spent years investigating a group of people who seemed independent of the world and society.
Uncle eventually gave up this investigation, but later, after returning from Shandong, learned that Mute Bottle was one of these people and hadn't aged.
They then began investigating Mute Bottle's background.
The investigation led to incredible stories, including a 'capture-the-corpse' event in Guangxi involving Chen Pi Si.
Chen Pi Si's men were sent to Guangxi to assist Vietnamese individuals who had discovered a large tomb and found a naked man, 'Ah Kun', tied up and covered in mud.
The Vietnamese used Ah Kun as bait to lure out something from the tomb.
After a struggle where blood splattered from the well, the Vietnamese sealed the well and fled.
Chen Pi Si, undeterred, returned to the tomb and found a scene of carnage, with Ah Kun sitting on a coffin amidst broken bodies.
This was the first encounter between Ah Kun (now Mute Bottle) and Chen Pi Si.
Brother Chu believes this story, though possibly exaggerated, provides a direction for Uncle's investigation.
He went to Guangxi to find clues about Mute Bottle and eventually found a village called Banai.
There, he identified Mute Bottle (known as Ah Kun) living in a simple house.
He secretly entered the house and took a photograph from a table under glass, which he later sent to the narrator.
Chen Pi Si likely noticed Brother Chu's investigation and ambushed him.
Brother Chu refuses to reveal the 'great secret' at the end, citing Uncle's aversion to the narrator's curiosity and his own moral obligation to Uncle.
He suggests the narrator look at the other photos under the glass in Mute Bottle's house in Banai to understand why he should stop investigating.
The narrator and his companions decide to travel to Banai, Guangxi, to investigate the photos mentioned by Brother Chu.
The journey involves flying to Nanning and then taking a train to Shangsi, followed by a car and walking to Banai.
The landscape of Guangxi is described as mountainous and lush.
They arrive in Banai near evening and find lodging at the home of Ah Gui, a local who runs a guesthouse.
Mute Bottle is eager to find the house mentioned by Brother Chu, but the narrator suggests they go the next day.
They have dinner, and the narrator observes the local lifestyle and the Yao girls preparing food.
The narrator learns about the village's improved economic situation due to tourism.
He inquires about Chen Pi Si and Vietnamese presence, learning that Vietnamese are further into the mountains.
He speculates that Chen Pi Si might be using the village as a meeting point for transactions with Vietnamese, disguised as tourists.
In the dining hall, Fatty points out a framed photograph on the wall containing many pictures.
One of the photos is a black-and-white picture, similar in style to the one from Brother Chu, showing Chen Wen Jin.
The other person in the photo is Ah Gui's father, wearing Yao traditional clothing, and a child is in the background.
Ah Gui confirms the photo was taken decades ago and that Wen Jin was part of an exploration team that investigated something in the nearby mountains.

concepts.name: 盗墓笔记之7：阴山古楼
concepts.context: Title of the novel.

concepts.name: 南派三叔
concepts.context: Author of the novel.

concepts.name: TXT小说天堂
concepts.context: Website hosting the novel.

concepts.name: 格尔木
concepts.context: Location of a traumatic experience and a sanatorium.

concepts.name: 秘密
concepts.context: Themes of uncovering secrets and their burdens.

concepts.name: 闷油瓶
concepts.context: A central character, also referred to as '哑巴张' and '小哥'.

concepts.name: 记忆
concepts.context: Mute Bottle's memory loss and desire to recover it.

concepts.name: 三叔
concepts.context: An important character, currently missing.

concepts.name: 胖子
concepts.context: A key companion of the narrator.

concepts.name: 潘子
concepts.context: Another companion of the narrator, loyal and efficient.

concepts.name: 陈皮阿四
concepts.context: An antagonist involved in various dealings.

concepts.name: 文锦
concepts.context: A character involved in past investigations.

concepts.name: 考察队
concepts.context: A group involved in investigations.

concepts.name: 楚哥
concepts.context: A former associate of Uncle, now imprisoned.

concepts.name: 老照片
concepts.context: Key pieces of evidence that drive the plot.

concepts.name: 广西
concepts.context: A region where significant events and investigations take place.

concepts.name: 巴乃
concepts.context: A village in Guangxi where Mute Bottle lived and where key information is found.

concepts.name: 阿坤
concepts.context: An earlier name for Mute Bottle.

concepts.name: 越南人
concepts.context: Individuals involved in a tomb raid in Guangxi.

concepts.name: 陈文锦
concepts.context: A character from an exploration team.

concepts.name: 阿贵
concepts.context: A resident of Banai who provides lodging and information.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured chronologically, beginning with the narrator's personal recovery and reflections, then moving into the practicalities of dealing with Mute Bottle's situation and seeking information. The narrative progresses through the discovery of clues, leading to an investigation into the past and culminating in a journey to a specific location to uncover more truths.
